page.title: UserManual:How can I identify entities that could be unified
UserManual:How can I identify errors in the knowledge base

revision.text:
Errors within the knowledge base of your wiki are identified by the [[Special:Gardening|Gardening Bots]]. The results are saved in the database and available in several places: *[[Special:GardeningLog|'''Gardening Log''']]: This is a browsable list of all gardening issues, where you can also filter for special types of errors. *'''Article edit mode''': If an error exists for an article that you are currently editing, it is shown in the '''Annotation hints''' box of the Semantic Toolbar. *[[Special:OntologyBrowser|'''Ontology Browser''']]: Errors are marked with small yellow warning icons . As soon as you click on them, a detailed error message will be shown. If an article has been edited since the last bot ran, the color of the icon will switch to green ]. *'''Query results''': If you create a query in table format, the same icons  will be shown for all articles with existing errors. Additionally, fields with missing annotations or wrong units are seperately marked. You can click these marks in order to access the edit mode of the corresponding page directly.
*[[Special:QueryInterface|'''Query Interface''']]: The preview mode of the query interface does also show gardening issues if you create a table format. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |url=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/04 |answer=Errors are displayed as small yellow warning icons |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Gardening| ]] [[UME discourse state::OntologyBrowser| ]] [[UME link::Help:Maintaining the knowledge base with the Gardening Bots| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I import articles

revision.text:
Depending on the project settings, a sysop can apply two types of import. They are both done with the page [[Special:Import|Special:Import]]: *'''Upload import''':Lets you import a file in a special XML|XML format which is produced while exporting pages from another wiki. *'''Transwiki import''', also called '''interwiki import''': Lets you import pages directly from another wiki. The settings of the target wiki determine which parts of the source wikis are enabled after "Transfer pages into namespace". One can specify a target namespace. Choosing the option "all" actually means "the same as the original". .
To import wiki pages from your file, simply click '''browse''' and locate the file on your local file system. Once the import process is done, one should see the new pages that were in the file. The wiki pages that have the same name as those in the file will be overwritten by the file content if the timestamp of the page that is in the file is newer. If an error occurred during the import, possibly because of a badly formatted XML file, then you might find that the import was partially undertaken. Repeating the import process all over again should be no problem since the pages are overwritten. If you included history information during export, you should also see information about the edits in the 'history' of the imported pages, and in the user contributions. The edits will not show up in 'recent changes'. This applies for both the time of the original edit and for the time of import. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/12 |answer=Depending on the project settings, a sysop can apply two types of '''import''', both with Special:Import page |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Importing articles| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I import emails to the wiki

revision.text:
To import emails to the wiki, follow these steps:
  1. Go to special page 'TermImport'.
  2. Choose '''Transport Layer Module: ConnectLocal''' to connect a local DAL module.
  3. Choose '''Data Acccess Module: "ReadPOP3"'''.
  4. Enter the name of the POP3-server as specified in your email client.
  5. Enter your email address.
  6. Enter your password.
  7. Choose '''Secure Sockets Layer''' to import emails with a secure encrypted connection (optional).
  8. Define an extra mapping policy article (optional)
  9. Define mapping policy, conflict policy and the input policy.
  10. Click '''Save''' and execute Term Import, to start the term import.
  11. After the successful import, you will get a link to the Gardening page at the bottom of the page.
  12. Click this link to see the bot's last/current activities .
  13. Click ''Log'' to see details of the last import.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/23 }} [[UME discourse state::DataImport| ]] [[UME link::Help:Importing emails to the wiki| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I import vocabulary
UserManual:How can I keep track of what is going on in the wiki

revision.text:
Notably,the most interesting special page is '''[[Special:Recentchanges]]'''. It displays all edits, file uploads, page moves, deletions and other actions done in the wiki. The menu that is on its upper section shows a collection of links which may be used to: * customize your display * limit the number of changes shown, * limit the the number of days shown or * restrict the results to edits to a particular namespace. * You can also hide edits marked as minor (don't forget that major changes can be flagged by a user as minor anyway).
There is one line in the recent changes which consists of several links: * '''diff'''- displays the difference to the previous revision of the page, * '''hist'''- links to the revision history of the page, * the link with the full title of the page brings you to the current version. If the title is in bold, it indicates that it is on your watchlist.
Following on there is a flag that describes the article modification type: *'''N'''-indicates that this is a new page, *'''m'''-indicates that this is a minor edit, *'''b'''-indicates that this edit was made by a bot.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |answer=Go to Special:Recentchanges |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:How can I get noticed when a page is changed| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I link to a subpage

revision.text:
A tree structure of pages is established by using forward slashes in pagenames. For example: * A/b is a '''''child '''''of A, hence A is a '''''parent''''' of A/b * A/b/c is a '''''child''''' of A/b while * A/a, A/b, and A/c are '''''siblings'''''. The top of the subpage automatically shows the body links to all ancestor pages without any corresponding wikitext. The links will show up even if the parent page does not exist, but the sequence of ancestors stops before any non-existing ancestor page.i.e. if the grandparent page does not exist, the parent page will not be shown either.
Like most '''page name''' letters , the first letter after the slash is case-sensitive: "/'''s'''ubpage" and "/'''S'''ubpage" are for example different pages. '''What links here''' and '''Related changes''' usually ignore these automatic links. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=A tree structure of pages is established by using forward slashes in pagenames |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I load an existing query into an article

revision.text:
To load an existing query using the WYSIWYG editor:
  1. Create a new page or edit an existing one with the WYSIWYG editor.
  2. Place the cursor in the editing area on the location where you want to insert the query.
  3. Click on the Query Interface button, and hit the Load query tab.
  4. Search through the existing queries ( please use the autocompletion to simplify your search ) .
  5. Click Search.
  6. Select your query:
    7. *Click Load selected query button if you want to make changes to the selected query before adding it. *Click the green Ok button if you want to add the selected query in its current form.
After clicking Ok button, the query interface will exit, you will automatically be returned to the WYSIWYG edit mode and the selected query will be loaded into your article. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise |year=2011 |date retrieved=2011/03/15 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Loading queries with the Query Interface 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I log in

revision.text: *You have to first ensure that your browser accepts cookies. *If you don't have an account, you can create a new one by clicking on the '''Create an account''' link. *If you have a '''Username''' and '''Password''', you just need to enter them in the respective fields and click on '''Log in.''' *If you click the box '''Remember me''',''' you will not have to give your password again whenever you access MediaWiki wiki from the same computer.''' {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/04 |answer=After creating an account you can log in to it by clicking on |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Logging in 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I make a double redirect

revision.text:
A so called double [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_redirects redirect] occurs when one attempts to create a redirect to a page that is also already a redirect. Such redirects will not work since multiple directing will not follow through to the end of the chain.
Users will instead just be presented with the relevant link, which is a view of the redirect page. This is a deliberate restriction, partly to prevent infinite loops and also to keep things simple. It serves the purpose of preventing the creation of rather unpleasant and complicated tree of redirects!
However this does mean that you should look out for double redirects and eliminate them by changing them to be 1-step redirects. This is mostly necessary only if you do a significant '''page move'''.
Use the '''what links here''' toolbox link to find double redirects to a particular page, or use '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Special:DoubleRedirects Special:DoubleRedirects]''' to search through the entire wiki.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=A double redirect (a page redirecting to a page which is itself a redirect) will not work. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I make a redirect to a page in the category namespace
UserManual:How can I make bots run automatically

revision.text:
To make bots run automatically please follow the following steps:
  1. Click '''Start''' > '''All Programs''' > '''Accessories''' > '''System Tools''' > '''Scheduled Tasks'''.
  2. Double click on '''Add Scheduled Task'''.
  3. Click '''Browse''', click the folder and file that you want to schedule i.e.C:\Programme\XAMPP\php\php.exe, and then click '''Open'''.
  4. Type a name for the task e. g. "Semantic Notification Bot", and then for example choose '''Daily'''.
  5. Click '''Next''', to specify the information about the day and time to run the task, and then click '''Next'''.
  6. Type the '''name '''and '''password ''' of the user who is associated with this task.
  7. Click '''Next''', and then click '''Finish''' once you have verified the choices that you have made. : The task now appears in the list of Scheduled Tasks.
  8. '''Open''' its properties.
    9. Remember that you have to change the fields "Execute" and "Execute in" in the Task tab: : *Execute  C:\Programme\XAMPP\php\php.exe SMW_startBot.php -b smw_semanticnotificationbot : *Execute in  C:\Programme\MediaWiki\HaloSMWExtension\extensions\SMWHalo\maintenance
    {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/10 }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticNotifications| ]] [[UME link::Help:Executing bots automatically| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I make the wiki pump primed

revision.text:
In order to use mathematical formulas, the wiki has to be pump primed i.e. four articles need to be created.
This needs only to be done only one time once the wiki system has been installed.
*Create the page '''Property:formula''' with this content:
<nowiki> [[has type::Type:Mathematical equation]] </nowiki>
*Create the pages '''Property:mathematical formula''' and '''Property:physical formula''' with this content:
<nowiki> [[has type::Type:Mathematical equation]] [[Subproperty of::Property:Formula]] </nowiki>
*Create the page '''List of formulas''' with this content:
<nowiki> ==List of all formulas== <ask> [[formula:=*]][[formula:=+]] </ask>
==List of all mathematical formulas== <ask> [[mathematical formula:=*]][[mathematical formula:=+]] </ask>
==List of all physical formulas== <ask> [[physical formula:=*]][[physical formula:=+]] </ask> </nowiki>
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=Use the special data type ''Mathematical equation''. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Managing formulae and proportions| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

revision.text:
Moving (renaming) a page amounts to you giving it another name. This is done using the '''Move''' tab that is at the top of the page. #'''Enter''' the new name. #'''Click''' on the ''movepage'' button. Under normal circumstances, you would wish to leave '''Move associated talk page''' option ticked.

page.title: UserManual:How can I move a category

revision.text:
Categories cannot be easily [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_move_(rename)_a_page%3F moved like other pages]. It is for this reason that one should choose the category names carefully.
Assuming that you have administrator rights and you wish to move a category, the easiest way to do this would be to: * create the new page, * delete the old one and then * change the tags in each member of the category manually or with a bot.
However, doing this '''loses the page history'''- this is quite not a huge problem if categories are used only for navigation.
However, this is undesirable in cases where the wiki is structured differently such that category pages contain significant amounts of text.
=== ===
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Create the new page, delete the old one and then change the tags in each member of the category |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Category| ]] [[UME link::Help:Moving and renaming a page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I name a page

revision.text:
Here are a few guidelines that you should follow while naming a page: * The following characters (the configuration is made in "''$wgLegalTitleChars''") are not allowed in page titles:                    '''< > [ ] | { }''' *The non-printable characters with values '''0''' through '''31''', and the '''delete''' character 127 in ASCII are also not allowed. *The backslash '''(\)''' results in complications: depending on where the pagename is used, the backslash may or may not be converted to a slash (/). *The first character of a page name cannot be a '''colon''' (:), '''space''' ( ), or '''underscore''' (_). *In page names a '''blank space''' is equivalent to an '''underscore'''. *A percent sign ('''%''') results in complications since the link may not work or interpret the sign together with some following characters as a code for a character depending on what follows in a link.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/12 |answer=The non-printable characters with values 0 through 31, and the |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Naming a page| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I organize Templates

revision.text:
One good way of dealing with templates in pages is to ensure that the [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_templates templates] are effectively used .This can be achieved by making them easy to find and use. One simple recommendable technique is to include an example on the [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_use_Templates template page]. For example: 
<noinclude>
==Usage==
Lets you establish a link to a subject:
{{NameOfTemplate|Term1+Term2+Term3}}
</noinclude>
Having done this, an editor can for example simply copy and paste the example and create a similar page. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/01 |answer=A simple technique is to include an example on the template page |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME discourse state::Template| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using templates to simplify annotations| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I perform export and export the full history

revision.text:
'''To perform export''': *'''Go to''' [[Special:Export|Special:Export]] and '''paste''' all your page names into the textbox, '''making sure''' there are no empty lines. *'''Click''' '''''Submit query'''''. *'''Save''' the resulting XML to a file using your browser's save facility. *'''Open''' the XML file in a text editor. *'''Scroll''' to the bottom to '''''check for error messages'''''.     Now you can use this XML file to [[Help:How can I export articles?|perform an import]].
'''To export the full history''':  A checkbox in the [[Special:Export|Special:Export]] interface selects whether to export the full history (all versions of an article) or the most recent version of articles. A maximum of 100 revisions are returned. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=There are at least four ways to export pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Export| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using history page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I point red link to a form
UserManual:How can I populate red-linked pages automatically
UserManual:How can I prevent edit conflicts

revision.text:
It is clear that edit conflicts are nerve-racking and rather time consuming. One may opt to adopt harmless edit habits such that one renders the edits less frequently. In doing this, one aims at making more edits to pages that have not been edited recently, for example those listed on [[Special:Ancientpages|ancient pages]].
Another way avoiding edit conflicts is to develop the habit of making single more extensive changes to articles, rather than frequent minor edits. In doing this, chances are that you are likely to get an edit conflict but on the other hand, you are less likely to be the source of edit conflicts to other users. The use of the "[[Help:How can I see a preview?|Show preview]]" button is also of great use in preventing possible blunders.
Wikipedia has an "In Use" notice in its [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_use_Templates Template]namespace users may activate if they have the intention of editing a page over a long period of time. This serves the purpose of preventing edit conflicts. Equally, you can put an <tt><nowiki>{{inuse}}</nowiki></tt> template on an article then proceed to make the major edit. Remember to remove this template once you finish editing.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=This page discusses '''edit conflicts''', and how to deal with them |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Solving edit conflicts 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I print a wiki page
UserManual:How can I print category

revision.text:
There are two ways to print [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_categories category] information: *SMW prints all categories assigned to some page. 
?Category
*SMW checks for one particular category.
?Category:Actor
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/18 |answer=There are two ways to print category information. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Category| ]] [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Working with query printouts 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I print format

revision.text:
Many printout statements can be further customized by giving a '''printout format''' This can be done added after a property name and separated by the symbol '''<tt>#</tt>'''.
If you have [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_properties properties] that support [[Help:Custom units|units]], queries can be used to determine which unit should be used for the output.
One would for example print the height in cm by making the following query:
''' ?height#cm '''
This presumes that the property height is aware of the unit «cm». Datatypes other than [[Type:Number|Type:Number]] may have different printout formats. See the types documentation for details.
For printouts of the form '''<tt>?Category:Actor</tt>''', the display format can be used to modify what SMW will display for cases where a page is (or is not) in the [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_categories category]. The following is an example:
''' ?Category:Actor#an actor, not an actor '''
This will show the text «an actor» for all pages that are actors. Otherwise it shows the text «not an actor» . This can, for example, also be used in combination with small images to display icons for certain categories.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/18 |answer= |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME link::Help:Working with query printouts 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I print property values

revision.text:
'''Property values''' are written simply as a question mark followed by the property name. Example: 
?population
* This prints the values for «population» of all query results. On [[Special:Ask|Special:Ask]], the result of each printout is shown in a table column that is labeled by the name of the property. One can change that label for a printout. Doing this would be very useful when using queries on wiki pages (it is not really relevant on [[Special:Ask|Special:Ask]] of course). The equals '''( = )'''symbol is used to change the label: 
?population = Number of inhabitants
* The above still prints population, but nor with the modified label in the table header. As mentioned above, property printouts may have an empty result for some pages, e.g. if something does not have any population. Property conditions with wildcards (see above) can be used to ensure that all elements in a query result have some value for the printed property, if this is desired. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/18 |answer=These are written simply as a question mark followed by the property name. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME link::Help:Working with query printouts 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I process an image

revision.text: The following processing actions can be taken on an Image: * '''Controlling the image format''' : border, frame, thumb, or frameless. * '''Aligning the image''' within a text accordingly: left, right, center, none. * '''Controlling the vertical alignment''' of the image within a text: baseline, sub, super, top, text-top, middle, bottom, text-bottom. * '''Resizing the image''' to the given '''width''' (or height) in pixels: {width} px.(or {height}px). * '''Resizing the image''' such that it fits within the given width and height in '''pixels''': {width}x{height}px. * '''Changing the image’s alternative text''' (alt=""): alt={alternative text}. *''' Changing the image’s alternative text''' (alt=""): alt={alternative text}. * '''Creating a random title''', '''URL''' or even a '''link to nowhere''': link={destination}. :* link= : Will display an image without its link, e.g. [[Image:Name.jpg|20px|link=Help:Images]].. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/02/04 }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding images to a page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I query data with forms
UserManual:How can I relate my type to the correct SI unit

revision.text:
The unit expression is a division of products of SI base units with an optional exponent. There must be at least the enumerator and an optional denominator.  The SI base units are: *'''m''' - Meter *'''kg''' - kilograms *'''s''' - Second *'''A''' - Ampere *'''K''' - Kelvin *'''mol''' - Mole *'''cd''' - Candela Products are written with '''*''' or blank. Exponents are introduced by '''^''', followed by a positive or negative integer.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Relating my type to the correct SI unit| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I reuse form elements
UserManual:How can I revert an edit

revision.text:
'''Reverting an edit''' involves returning a page to a previous version of its history, as documented in the corresponding tab. In the context of the English Wikipedia three revert rule, a revert is defined more broadly as the undoing of another editor's work by returning ''any part of a page'' to an older version.
Latest versions of MediaWiki allow editors to revert a single edit from the history of a page without simultaneously undoing all constructive changes that have been made since.
To do this, view the diff for the edit, and '''click''' on '''''undo''''' above the newer version. The software will attempt to create an edit page with a version of the article in which the undesirable edit has been removed but all later edits will be retained. There is a default edit summary which may be changed. It is also possible to make further modifications before saving.
This feature does away with the need to manually re-do useful changes that were made after the edit that is reverted.
This will however fail if undoing the edit would cause conflict with later edits.
For example, if edit number 1000 adds a paragraph and edit number 1005 modifies that paragraph, it will be impossible to automatically undo edit 1000. In this case, you must look for ways of resolving the problem manually.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer= |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Reverting an edit 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I search for help articles

revision.text:
All help articles are stored in your local wiki in the '''Namespace:UserManual''' and are annotated with the properties "UME discourse state" and "UME link". Formulate a query e. g. 
{{#ask: [[UME discourse state::+]]
| ?UME discourse state 
|}}
and you will get a list of all imported help articles. Furthermore all desired help pages are stored in SMW Forum in the category Context sensitive help article. {{ShowComments|show=True}} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Context Sensitive Help| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I see a preview

revision.text:
Below the edit box is a '''Show preview''' button. Pressing this will show you what the article will look like without actually saving it. It is strongly recommended that you use this prior to saving. This allows you to check what the page will look like first and to check that you haven't made any errors. It also prevents the need for multiple saves. Saving the same article a large number of times in quick succession makes it harder for people to check what changes have been made, and clogs up the page history. It is helpful, however, to save the page before moving, breaking apart, or combining sections of the article, if you have been making small edits to the article. The difference display is not good at showing paragraph moves, and will not display the small edits clearly if sections are then moved around. Saving only once is also a way of avoiding edit conflicts, as people will not see the article on recent changes, and therefore they are less likely to try editing it at the same time as you. If you are logged in, you can set your preferences to show the preview positioned before the edit box instead of after it. If you select this option, the preview will be displayed above the edit box when you click the '''Show preview''' button while editing a page.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=Below the edit box is a '''Show preview''' button |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Preview| ]] [[UME link::Help:Seeing a preview| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I see all pages that link to a page
UserManual:How can I see if my page is protected

revision.text:
There are two possibilities of checking whether a page is protected:
# The first one involves going in the '''edit''' or '''creation''' mode. While in this mode, one sees an ACL panel at the top of your page which has the details about the page's protection status. # The second option involves you '''Adding'''  /ACL:Page/  to your page link as follows: :http:<''your wiki url''>'''/ACL:Page/'''<''name of your page''> {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/03/30 }} [[UME discourse state::HaloACL| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a standard ACL| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I see the contributions of a user

revision.text: If the user has an '''account /username''' you just need to open the user's user page and click ''User '''''contributions''' : If the user has no login name, there are two ways of looking at their contributions: # By clicking on the IP address in '''Recent Changes''' or '''Page History'''. # By putting the the IP address in the search box and press '''Go'''. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=''User contributions pages''' list the edits that a particular user has made |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Detecting user contributions| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I see the differences in history

revision.text:
A '''diff''' is the difference between two versions of a page. It can be viewed from the page history. For every version there are potentially two radio buttons: the left column is for selecting the older version, the right column for selecting the newer one. Pressing '''Compare selected versions''' gives the difference between the two versions.
For special cases (the diff for a single edit or between an old and the current version) other possibilities are clicking '''''cur'' '''or '''''last''''' in the page history or on the Recent Changes page. The diff is also shown during an edit conflict so you can see exactly what you need to reintegrate. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=A '''diff''' is the difference between two versions of a page. It can be viewed from the |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::History| ]] [[UME link::Help:Finding differences with history of articles 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I see the history of a page
UserManual:How can I see the size of a page

revision.text:
There is a parser function '''PAGESIZE''' which serves this purpose.
In older versions of MediaWiki finding the size of the wikitext of a page can only be done indirectly:
*search; use suitable search terms to get few other results; e.g. for Variable one can use the search terms:
::de Wikipedia Variablen zh Help 变量
:which conveniently gives no other results, and shows that the size is, at the time of this writing, "0.8KB (142 words)".
*for a page in the main [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_are_Namespaces namespace], also Shortpages and Special:Longpages can be used.
*the text can also be copied in a local editor and saved; note that small deviations can be due to newline taking one or two bytes.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=There is a parser function PAGESIZE |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I select method in a new web service

revision.text:
To select a method in a new web service, you just need to '''choose''' one of these methods for calling the web service: * '''HTTP-get'''. * '''HTTP-post'''. In most cases, HTTP-get is appropriate.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/10 }} [[UME discourse state::WebService| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining a web service using GUI| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}
