UserManual:How can I show the values of a property in the results

revision.text:
1. Go to the special page '''Special:QueryInterface ''' or if you are using the WYSIWYG editor, click on the Query interface button in the WYSIWYG toolbar -this button has a small question mark and a small arrow and is located on the lower right section of the WYSIWYG editor toolbar.
  2. Specify your property name by entering its name in the text input box.
  3. Define the '''Property value''' as follows: * Activate the '''Value must be set''' checkbox, to display only the results that include the mentioned property. For example, if you only wish to display only the pages that have a value for the Property '''number of inhabitants''', you would check the '''Value must be set''' checkbox.
    4. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/10 }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Complete example of query formulation| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I solve common problems of Semantic Forms (Data design issues)
UserManual:How can I solve common problems of Semantic Forms (MediaWiki issues)

revision.text:
*If a template contains section headings (like "==Section 1=="), when the template is displayed on a page each section heading will have its own '''Edit''' link. Such links are not desirable, since they will take the user to editing the template, rather than the actual page in question. The easiest way to avoid this problem is to place the string <nowiki>"__NOEDITSECTION__"</nowiki> anywhere within that template; this will remove all section-edit links from any page that contains that template. *If you encounter an error like "Memory Size Exhausted", it may help to increase the memory limit for PHP, by adding the following to LocalSettings.php: "ini_set( 'memory_limit', '32M' );"
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=There are different solutions for the most common problems of Semantic Forms |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I solve common problems of Semantic Forms (Semantic MediaWiki issues)

revision.text:
*If you get an error on any page reading something like '''Table ''smw_relations'' doesn't exist''' or '''Table ''smw_attributes'' doesn't exist''', it means you haven't installed, or haven't finished installing, the Semantic MediaWiki extension. If you've set up the SMW code and added the right lines to LocalSettings.php, probably all you need to do is create the new semantic database tables - go to '''Special:SMWAdmin '''and '''press''' the button.
*To get rid of the semantic '''factbox''' that appears at the bottom of most pages, add the following line to your '''LocalSettings.php''' file: "$smwgShowFactbox = SMW_FACTBOX_HIDDEN;"
*To get rid of the '''error''' image that appears for property values that are supposedly incorrect, add the following line to your '''LocalSettings.php''' file: "$smwgInlineErrors = false;"
* If one or more of your fields can contain internal links entered by users (e.g., "This is a <nowiki>[[cat]]</nowiki>"), and you want those fields to be saved correctly by SMW, add the following line to your LocalSettings.php file, under the inclusion of SMW: "$smwgLinksInValues = true;"
*For versions of Semantic MediaWiki before 1.2, if you change the names of any semantic properties within a template, that data is not refreshed in pages that use that template until those pages are re-saved. This can be fixed by either upgrading to the latest version of SMW.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=There are different solutions for the most common problems of Semantic Forms |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I solve edit conflicts

revision.text:
If User 2 only made small changes, and User 1 made large changes, he may choose to work from User 1's version, and re-merge his changes in. User 2 might choose to add some text like "via edit conflict" to warn User 1 and others that he had to do this - User 1 can then [[:meatball:PeerReview|peer review]] his merging for accuracy.
If User 2 made large changes, and User 1 made small changes, he may choose to work from his version. One option is for User 2 to copy the bottom text into the top text (or just copy over the one section of the top text, if User 2 was section editing), with an appropriate edit summary (eg '''via edit conflict, will remerge'''). Then User 2 can view the page history, determine User 1's changes, and re-apply them to his version, in a separate edit.
If both User 1 and User 2 made large changes, matters become complicated, and User 1 and User 2 just have to do the best they can. For example, if both User 1 and User 2 simultaneously add a large section of text on the same subject, then it may be best for User 2 to submit his changes, and then for User 1 and User 2 to both have a look at the two versions and decide between themselves which version is better.
User 2 should not just post his changes over the top of User 1's. We assume good faith - mistakes are occasionally made, and newcomers may not understand the edit conflict window. However, User 2 must not routinely ignore edit conflicts. It is absolutely not acceptable for User 2 to overwrite User 1 out of laziness. We encourage contributors to double-check their merges by using the [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_see_the_differences_in_history diff] feature.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=This page discusses '''edit conflicts''', and how to deal with them |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Solving edit conflicts 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I start a new page

revision.text:
There are several ways of starting up a new page:
#Using '''Wikilinks'''. #Using the '''URL'''. #From the '''search page'''.
*Create redirects to your new page, don't forget to setup redirects when you create a page. *You can '''protect''' the page, if desired, to prevent normal users editing it. This requires sysop permissions.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=The most popular way is by using wikilinks: create an internal link to an inexistent page. Clicking on this link (which is colored in red), will take you to your newly created page. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a new page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I start a new page Using Wikilinks

revision.text:
MediaWiki makes it very easy to link wiki pages using a standard syntax. If you (or anyone else) creates a link to an article that doesn't exist yet, the link will be coloured red, like this. #'''Click''' a red link.
#'''Type''' your text in the '''''edit page''''' for the new article. #'''Click''' '''''save''''' and the new page will be created. Once the page has been created, the link will change from red to blue (purple for pages you've visited) indicating that the article now exists.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=Clicking a red link, will take you to the edit page for the new article. Simply type your text, click save and the new page will be created. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a new page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I start a new page Using the URL

revision.text:
The URL to an article in the wiki usually looks almost like this: *http://www.example.net/index.php/'''ARTICLE'''    or *http://www.example.net/wiki/'''ARTICLE''' To create a new page my modifying the URL you should:
  1. '''Replace''' '''ARTICLE''' with the name of the page you wish to create.
    You will be taken to a blank page which indicates that there is currently no article with that name.
  2. '''Click ''' on the '''edit''' page tab at the top of the page which will take you to the edit page for that article.
  3. '''Type''' your text.
  4. Then click '''submit'''.
    5. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=The most popular way is by using wikilinks: create an internal link to an inexistent page. Clicking on this link (which is colored in red), will take you to your newly created page. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a new page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I start a new page from the search page

revision.text:
If you search for a page that doesn't exist through the '''search box''' and the '''go''' button that is to the page's left , you will be provided with a '''create the new page''' link. Following this link lets you create an article about the page you searched for.
<noinclude>{{ShowComments|show=True}}</noinclude> {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=The most popular way is by using wikilinks: create an internal link to an inexistent page. Clicking on this link (which is colored in red), will take you to your newly created page. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::UnifiedSearch| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a new page 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I submit changes in the AAM

revision.text:
All the changes you make are kept in your browser until you save them. The '''Don't forget to save your work''' section enables two buttons whenever you annotate something. #Click on '''Save annotations''' to save your new or modified annotations and '''stay in annotation mode'''. #Click '''Save & exit''' to save your changes and '''switch to viewing mode'''. Once you save your work, a message indicates whether it was successfully accomplished and the save buttons are disabled.
If you try to leave a changed article, a popup window will always ask you if you want to save your modifications.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=Click |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME link::Help:Accessing the Semantic toolbar via annotation mode 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I turn a link into a property

revision.text:
Consider the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin Wikipedia article on Berlin]. This article contains many links to other articles, such as «Germany», «European Union», and «United States». However, the link to «Germany» has a special meaning: it was put there since Berlin is the capital of Germany. To make this knowledge available to computer programs, one would like to «tag» the link
<nowiki>[[Germany]]</nowiki>
in the article text, identifying it as a link that describes a «capital property». With SMW+, this is done by putting a property name and '''::''' in front of the link inside the brackets, thus:
<nowiki>[[capital of::Germany]]</nowiki>
In the article, this text still is displayed as a simple hyperlink to «Germany». The additional text <tt>capital of</tt> is the name of the '''property''' that classifies the link to Germany. As in the case of categories, the name of the property is arbitrary, but you should try to re-use properties that already appear elsewhere.
To simplify this re-use, every property has its own article in the wiki, just as every category has an article. You can see all the properties in use in the wiki with the [[Special:Properties]] page. Just as category articles are prefixed with <tt>Category:</tt>, all property articles are prefixed with <tt>Property:</tt> to distinguish them from other articles. So you can also also use the [[Special:Search]] page to find existing properties. As with categories, a property's article can be empty, but it is strongly recommended to add a description that explains the intent of the property and its proper usage.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=Tag the link in the article text |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Turning a link into a property 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I turn forms into tabbed sections

revision.text:
you can turn a form into sections, with a tab interface to navigate between them, using the Header Tabs extension.
#Install Header Tabs extension.
#Add a top-level section wherever you want a tab to appear, of the form "=Tab 1=".
#Add the tag "" near the bottom of the form, right above the "standard input" declarations.
#Place tab declarations (between templates/within templates), to split up the fields of a template into different tabs.
*Use such tabs, in a similar way, to display the actual data pages.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |answer=If you think that a particular form is too long for users to fill out comfortably, you can divide it into sections, with a tab interface that helps to navigate between them, using the Header Tabs extension. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I update annotations from changed templates

revision.text:
'''Template Materialization''' is a part of the '''Gardening Toolbox'''. You can get there by selecting the Gardening page on SpecialPages or you can use the shortcut in the navigation toolbox that is on the left.
*Select 'Materialize template content' on the left (Please note that one needs to have '''Gardening rights''' for one to use this bot!) *After a short while you'll see the possible parametrization to the right.
'Apply only to touched templates' means that the update is incremental. Only the pages that use templates that have been changed since the last update will be processed. One exception is the first template materialization. This is always done completely to make sure the wiki content is consistent.
*Press the '''Run''' button. *Having done this, a new row indicating the running process will be shown in the bot activity table. *You will get an email notification when the process has finished that is if you had given an email address in your user profile.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=Use the 'Materialize template'-bot in the gardening toolbox |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Gardening| ]] [[UME link::Help:Updating annotations from changed templates| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I upload and annotate media

revision.text:
To upload media, first add the template {{RMList|show=True}} to the article '''1.''' Inspect the article and see which rich media files are related to your article.
'''2.''' Enter the target filename in the article you wish to upload and click '''attach document or media'''.
The upload file window will then pop up.
'''3.''' Browse through your local system and select the target file and click '''Upload File and save metadata''' button.
'''4.''' Inspect your attached media.
You will be able to:
* Delete an attached file, using the delete icon.
* Open the attached file, using format icon.
* Enrich it with metadata, by clicking the title of an attached file.
'''Annotating media:'''
'''1.''' Click the title of the file you wish to enrich with metadata. If you wish to edit metadata you should open the article in the "edit with forms"-mode.
'''2.''' Enter the metadata in the corresponding fields.
'''3.''' Click '''Save''' '''The file’s target page will be appropriately enriched with the metadata that you entered.''' {{ShowComments |show=True }} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/23 }} [[UME discourse state::EditWYSIWYG| ]] [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Uploading and annotating media| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I upload media with the WYSIWYG-editor

revision.text: While editing a page, you may upload documents, images, audio and video files. To do this: #'''Open''' an article (''Create a '''new '''page or ''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_edit_pages ''edit'']'' an '''existing''' page'') in the '''''WYSIWYG''''' -Mode. #'''Click '''on the '''''Upload media''''' button. #'''Click''' on the '''''Browse''''' button and '''choose''' the media file you wish to upload from your local file system.(Not all file-types are supported) #'''Click''' the plus button  which will open the '''''Meta information''''' box, to add some Meta information to the file you are uploading. '''             '''a .  '''Check''' whether an entry has been made in the '''''Uploaded by''''' field. If not '''add''' your name.              b .  '''Add''' the name of the person or company who holds the rights to this file.              c .  '''Enter''' a short description of this file.              d .  '''Enter''' additional related articles. These are the articles where the file shall be attached.       5.  Finally click  '''''Upload file''''' and ''''' '''''save '''''the metadata''''' button. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 }} [[UME discourse state::EditWYSIWYG| ]] [[UME link::Help:Upload media with the WYSIWYG interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use Concepts for Semantic Search

revision.text:
'''Concept''' pages as such can be browsed to view the contents of some concept, similar to category pages. But they can also be used in other '''semantic queries''' just like categories. For example, the following query would show all pages in the above concept of events which are also located in Germany:
<nowiki>[[Concept:Semantic Web events 2008]] [[located in Germany]]</nowiki>
Note that this would look almost the same if we would have a category called «Semantic Web events 2008». therefore, concepts are also like stored queries that can be reused in other queries if desired.
SMW's '''inline queries''' may also use concepts, and in some cases even the concept description is used to beautify an output.
Concept descriptions are also included in SMW's '''RDF export''' in form of '''''OWL''''' class descriptions, so that other Semantic Web tools can download an dreuse the concept descriptions. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |answer=It is possible to store queries in Semantic MediaWiki on dedicated pages, called |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticSearch| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Concepts| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use Display templates

revision.text:
The '''Display Templates''' were introduced to the Automatic Semantic Forms extension in order to visualize the created annotations.
One can associate a Display Template with a category via the "Use display template" property. Each time, you edit an instance with an automatic form, the Automatic Semantic Forms extension checks whether the direct super categories of the instance have an associated display template and then adds those Display Templates to the instance.
'''Note''' : The '''Use display template''' property is not inherited from super categories.
You can use the Display Template which has one template parameter named '''categories''' to render the created annotations in various ways such as with the parser functions and so on.
One major advantage of the Display Templates feature is the separation of the annotation creation, which is done by the SilentAnnotations parser function, and annotation rendering, which is done via Display Templates. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise |year=2011 |date retrieved=2011/03/15 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using 'Display templates'| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use LDAP authentication
UserManual:How can I use Semantic Forms

revision.text:
*Semantic Forms is an extension to MediaWiki that allows users to add, edit and query data using forms without any programming. Forms can be created and edited not just by administrators, but by users themselves.
*Forms can be used to edit the data in an existing page, and you can enable an '''edit with form''' tab to show up on any page.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=Forms can also be used to edit the data in an existing page, and you can enable an 'edit with form' tab to show up on any page; see The 'edit with form' tab. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use Templates

revision.text:
Template names have a '''Template:''' prefix and they may be created just like any other wiki page. Templates are wiki pages which can be used in other pages in three ways: *{{Name}} includes the content of the template at the moment the page containing it is fetched "[[Template:Name]]". *{{subst:Name}} inserts the content of the template into the code of the page in a form that is editable normally "[[Template:Name]]" after you have saved your text. *{{msgnw:Name}} when the page containing it is fetched, includes the template in a form that displays it as raw wiki syntax, like does.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=Create a template like any normal page, but with the Template: prefix, and include it in your pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using templates to simplify annotations| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use autocompletion in the wiki
UserManual:How can I use chemical equations

revision.text: A chemical equation consists of reactants an arrow and the products. These products may be intermediate products that further react to other products Reactants and products are concatenations of chemical formulas. The formulas are connected with a + or a * (or x) (which yields ●). The wiki offers the type '''Type:Chemical equation'''. Attributes with this type are checked for correctness with the rules above. Only syntactical correctness can be checked i.e. chemical rules can still be violated. Chemical equations consist mainly of chemical formulas. These are connected by the following symbols (connectors) in wiki text: *->: → (Reaction) *<-: ← (Reaction) *<->: ⇌ (Equilibrium) *+: + ** or x: ● There must be no spaces within the arrows. An equation must also begin and end with a formula. There must only one connector between formulas. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=Use Chemical formulas and connectors. Use Type:Chemical equation. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using chemical equations 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use chemical formulas
UserManual:How can I use custom units of measurement

revision.text:
Units can be used for properties of [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Type:Number Type:Number], and make annotation more flexible: everybody can view and enter data in his or her preferred unit without restricting mutual understanding. For example, some people might prefer a distance given in '''''miles''''' over one given in '''''km'''''. In other cases, it might not be suitable to display a distance in '''''km''''' if '''''microns''''' are more appropriate.
Through the use of floating-point numbers, a single type can support a broad range of units. For example, a single length type can easily support both light years and nanometers. However, if someone uses a property '''''Elevation''''' to specify the height of a mountain, then it would hardly be useful to display this value in '''''light years''''' or '''''nano'''''meters.
SMW+ allows you to specify which units a property should display from all the units its type supports. This information is specific to the property : two properties can both use Type:Length while still having different appearances in the wiki. If no preferences on display are given, a property will display all of its type's units, with the main unit (the one with conversion factor 1) first.
To specify custom display units, add the special property [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Property:Display_units display units] to the property's page, mentioning each unit you want displayed separated by commas. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=N-ary properties are annotated in the same way as normal ones |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using custom units 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use inferencing

revision.text:
[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:How_can_I_use_semantic_search Semantic search] can be used to find pages based on the information that users have entered about them into the wiki. This simplifies many tasks, but it still requires that semantic information is entered manually in the first place. In some cases, one would expect the wiki to be «smarter» and to deduce some facts even if they were not entered directly. In some cases, SMW can draw such inferences '''automatically'''.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=TIn some cases, SMW can draw such inferences automatically, as described in this article. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticSearch| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Basic Inferencing| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use lists
UserManual:How can I use mathematical formulas

revision.text:
*The SMW offers the special data type ''Mathematical equation''. By now, there is no special parsing and syntax checking for values of this type. But future versions of SMW might provide real computing capabilities with mathematical equations. Properties that should use this type must contain the following type definition: <nowiki> [[has type::Mathematical equation]] </nowiki>
*The reminder feature is supported by three pumpprimed wiki property pages: '''Property:formula''', '''Property:mathematical formula''' and '''Property:physical formula'''. The last two are subproperties of the first. Here is an example for an annotated physical formula:
<nowiki> [[physical formula:=f = m*a]] </nowiki>
*The RME modeler should be able to find interesting formulas in the wiki. The pumpprimed page ''List of formulas'' serves this purpose. It lists all annotated formulas together with a link to the page where they are defined. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/25 |answer=Use the special data type ''Mathematical equation''. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using mathematical formulas| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use namespaces

revision.text:
Namespaces allow, among other things, a separation of content from policy and discussion. They encourage separation of the pages of a wiki into a core set intended for public viewing, and private information intended for the editing community.
This core set is the main namespace. Other namespaces that are also useful to viewers are:
*the image namespace (with the full-size images) *the category namespace (for navigation) *the help pages and the preferences page (as far as they concern viewing)
'''By default''', searches and the random page feature are restricted to the main namespace, thus the user interface is directed towards readers who are not part of the community. Note that this separation of community and readership is not a feature of many wiki engines. It may not be required for your editing community. You are always free to put discussion and policy in the main namespace, if you desire.
On most Wikimedia wikis, pages in the main namespace and a few other ones are actively policed by the community, with inappropriate content being quickly removed. The rules for the other namespaces are generally more relaxed.
User contributions can only show all or be restricted to a namespace of choice. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=Namespaces allow, among other things, a separation of content from policy and discussion |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using Namespaces 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use piped links

revision.text:
A '''piped link''' is an internal link or interwiki link where the link target and link label are both specified. It is needed if the two are not identical such that the link label is not equivalent to the link target and the last word is extended. This lets you link a word or phrase within the text of a page instead of using the ‘refer to’ or ‘see also’ phrase even if the wording does not exactly correspond with the name of the target page. With a suitable browser and depending on the preferences that are set, one can still see the link target such that the name shows up in a hover box and is also shown in the status bar when you point to the link. For instance: 
[[coffeehouse setup|How to set up a coffee house]]
will show: [[Coffeehouse setup|How to set up a coffee house]] An alternative to this would be to use [[Help:Handling redirects 1.5.3|redirect pages]].For example, let’s say that you desire to create [[How to set up a coffee house|How to set up a coffee house]].To do this, you should use [[How to set up a coffee house]] and make this a redirect to coffeehouse setup.
There are however a few '''disadvantages''' of this method: * The pop-up does not show the page to which it will redirect to . * "Related changes" will show the changes in the '''redirect page'' and not those of the redirect target. * The redirect message on the target page slightly clutters it. Combining a piped link and a redirect, one can provide some information that is not the name of the page one links to in the hover box, such as the value of a unit in terms of other units. In that case one can make a page whose pagename is the info one wants in the link title, and which redirects to a page with a more appropriate name. For external links a space is used instead of a pipe character. {{ShowComments|show=True}} {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=A |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using piped links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use semantic search
UserManual:How can I use tables
UserManual:How can I use talk pages
UserManual:How can I use templates to simplify annotations
UserManual:How can I use the Data Import Repository

revision.text:
The special page Special:DataImportRepository gives you an overview of all Wiki Web Service Definitions (WWSD) that are defined in your wiki. You need to be logged in with administrative user rights in order to edit or update a Term Import and to confirm web services.
;Update * Click '''Update''' to update all the data that you have integrated into your wiki articles with a Web Service call. * Results of web service calls are updated automatically in accordance to the Display Policy and the Query Policy that you have specified in your WWSD. You may additionally perform manual updates on this special page.
;Confirm * Click '''Confirm''' to confirm new WWSDs so that they may be used in wiki articles. * The web services that has been created or those that has been modified may only be called once. This service may not be used again until a Wiki Sysop reviews and confirms the WWSD. The users may thereafter use the web service indefinitely. The WWSDs that have already been confirmed are labeled as "confirmed".
;Term Import definitions
The Term Import Repository lists all valid Term Import definitions that have been declared in the Wiki. You can edit a Term Import definition in the graphical user interface and manually update its results here. Updating the web service call results {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::DataImport| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME discourse state::WebService| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using the Data Import Repository| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use the Go button

revision.text:
If you use the '''Go button''' wisely, it will allow you to quickly jump to your most frequently used pages. It is also recommendable to use it for specific searches – It will either way undertake a normal search anyway if there is no match. It there was a match it instantaneously takes you to your desired page. Entering an IP address and pressing '''go''' will display the '''User contributions''' that were made from this address. This is a special feature. One stands to benefit from making use of the existing redirects and namespaces aliases. Notably, one can use short alias "user:" instead of longer localized version in most Wikimedia projects. Depending on the contents of '''SMW:Nogomatch''' there may be a link to the edit page of the non-existent page. A useful advantage of this is the possibility of shifting to a page that is on another wiki by adding the interwiki prefix. Having said this, we note that using the text "create an article with this title" would not be accurate for the link for the case of an existing page. The CSS-class of the link is also "new" and not not "extiw".
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |answer=The function of the Go button is to directly navigate to a page which name is entered in the search field |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME discourse state::UnifiedSearch| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using the search box 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use the ParserFunctions extension
UserManual:How can I use the RDF export functionality

revision.text:
You can easily access the generated RDF via the page [[Special:ExportRDF]] by entering a list of articles into the input field. The export will contain one OWL/RDF specification with various description blocks for exported elements. In addition to the requested articles, the export will also contain basic declarations for any further elements (such as mentioned instances, properties, and classes).
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=via the page [[Special:ExportRDF]] |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Export| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Exporting Data with RDF Export Functionality| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use the autocompletion in forms

revision.text:
Autocomplete can be used on: *All the values of a specific '''property''', add autocomplete on property=property-name to the field definition. *The names of all pages in a '''category''', add autocomplete on category=category-name *The names of all pages in a '''namespace''', add autocomplete on namespace=namespace-name If you want use autocomplete based on the values in an '''external URL''', which lets you get autocompletion values from any external system, you should: #Create a page/web service that takes in a substring via the query string, and displays a set of autocompletion values; the values should be in JSON format, and look like the JSON returned by the MediaWiki API, this also makes it easy to autocomplete on the values from another wiki. #Decide on a short string to represent this URL. #Add a line to LocalSettings.php: 
$sfgAutocompletionURLs['URL-identifier-string'] = 'URL'; #Add the parameter autocomplete from url=URL-identifier-string to the relevant field in the form definition. *Disable autocompletion, if it's enabled by default for a field, by adding the parameter "no autocomplete" to the field's definition. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/03 }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I use the calendar

revision.text:
To display a calendar on a page, showing all events that have a date represented by the property:'''Has date''', add the following to the page: 
{{#semantic_calendar:Has date}}
Note that you can replace '''Has date''' with whatever property name you use. You can also add a set of queries to filter the events being displayed; the query format used is the same as that used for Semantic MediaWiki's '''ask''' inline queries. You can also display multiple sets of data on the same calendar, by separating the different date properties, and their corresponding sets of filter queries, with semicolons. There should be the same number of date properties and filter-query sets. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/16 |answer=To display a calendar on a page, add |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using the calendar| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I view a redirect
UserManual:How can I view all semantic links and properties of a page

revision.text:
*'''Special:Browse''' offers a simple browsing interface for the computer-readable data of SMW+. You start by entering the name of a page. The semantic browsing then displays on the left all semantic links that lead to that page and on the right all semantic properties of that page (similar to the content of the Factbox). *By clicking on the icon [[Image:Browse icon.png|Browser button]], you can 'semantically' browse to another article.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=You can view all semantic links and properties by using |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Summarized Semantic Data in Factbox| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I view comments stored in the wiki

revision.text:
A list of all existing comments may be accessed in three ways: * Via the category page * Via the specialpage * Via an inline query '''Via the category page''':
This is possible since every comment is an instance of the ''Category:Comment''. One may thus get a list of all comments by visiting the page Category:Comment.
'''Via the specialpage''':
'''1.''' Go to Special:SpecialPages > Lists of pages > All pages with prefix.
'''2.''' Choose: Comment as prefix. Doing this will display a list of all existing comments.
'''Via an inline query''':
The inline query for listing all comments has the the following structure:
{{#ask: [[Category:Comment]]
| format=table
| merge=false
|}}


{{ShowComments |show=True }} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/23 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:How to view comments| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I work with Semantic Forms

revision.text:
Below are a few guidelines for using Semantic Forms:
  1. '''Figure''' out your data structure first. *What types of pages will the site have? *What data will be contained on each one? : It's good to have a starting plan.
  2. '''Create properties'''.
  3. '''Create templates'''.
  4. '''Create forms'''.
  5. '''Create categories'''.
  6. '''Enable links to forms'''. Besides creating categories that have a default form, there are other steps which you can take to enable the users access the forms that you have created. These include: * '''Adding links''' to add data in the sidebar and elsewhere, * '''Setting default forms''' and alternate forms on properties, * '''Making links''' to nonexistent pages appear in read and consequently pointing to the forms which may be used to create such pages. These actions are all explained further below.
  7. '''Adding data'''. You should also add data to the site, using your new forms, to make sure that forms, templates and categories are working the way you want them to.
  8. '''Adding links''' on sidebar and elsewhere. The sidebar, which can be edited from the "Me-diaWiki:Sidebar" page inEnglish-language wikis, should also have links which are used to add each of the data types and to the categories for each of these data types. You may also include such links on the main page and elsewhere.
  9. '''Customizing'''. Once the structure is in place, you can customize all you want by changing the look-and-feel of the entire wiki by: *setting up the various templates, and forms, *adding and changing fields, *adding and changing inline queries.

    10. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=A form should populate the template or templates that this page type contains |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I work with Semantic Forms (Create categories)
UserManual:How can I work with Semantic Forms (Create forms)

revision.text:
Now you can create forms to allow users to easily add and edit pages of vari-ous types. There should be one form per page type; a form should populate the template or templates that this page type contains.
As in earlier versions, there's a special page to create new forms: '''CreateForm'''.
There has been a feature request that has been made by several users who made a request that the '''CreateProperty''','''CreateTemplate''' and '''CreateForm''' special pages should to be able to edit existing property/template/form pages, and not just create new ones.
However, looking at the programming aspect, this is harder to implement than creating new pages, because it requires parsing. For the time being and in the near future, modifying existing properties, templates and forms will have to continue being done manually.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=A form should populate the template or templates that this page type contains |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How can I work with Semantic Forms (Create properties)
UserManual:How can I work with Semantic Forms (Create templates)
UserManual:How can annotate within the WYSIWYG-editor

revision.text:
To annotate within the WYSIWYG-editor, please follow these steps:
1. '''Click''' on the Semantic toolbar button to open the semantic toolbar.
2. '''Select''' text.  
*If a selection can be annotated, the context menu for category and property is shown and filled with the selected value *for the fields (except property name).
*If the selection cannot be annotated, an error message appears.
*If already annotated text is selected, the selection must span the whole annotation and the appropriate contextmenu (category or property) must appear with all values prefilled in the text fields.
3. After '''adding '''the annotations you can see the changes in the page.
4. '''Save''' the page. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/03 }} [[UME discourse state::EditWYSIWYG| ]] [[UME link::Help:Accessing the Semantic toolbar via the editors 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How do I access the Query interface
UserManual:How does the Go button work

revision.text:
The '''Go''' button is way much more complex than percieved. This is how it works,always and successively if there is no match found:
  1. It first checks whether there is a page whose name is an '''exact match for the entered name'''.(Note that most projects have case-insensitivity of the first character of the whole page name, and in the case of a namespace prefix, of the first character after that). For example, if you entered "the test Page", MediaWiki might navigate to [[The test Page|The test Page]].
  2. It then tries the '''lower case option''': [[The test page|the test page]].
  3. Followed by the text with all the '''first letters of every word in uppercase''': [[The Test Page|The Test Page]].
  4. Finally it looks up the text with '''all parts in uppercase''': [[THE TEST PAGE|THE TEST PAGE]].
If none of the above variations of the text are found, a full text search is performed as if you had clicked the '''Search''' button. This '''Go''' button generates little server load, and therefore usually remains functional even if the fulltext search is deactivated for performance reasons. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=The function of the Go button is to directly navigate to a page which name is entered in the search field |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME discourse state::UnifiedSearch| ]] [[UME link::Help:Hints for handling the search 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How should I annotate the essence of an article

revision.text:
The following steps should be followed if you are editing any random article with a view of annotating the essence of the current article i.e. the text that is the central in the respective article. To annotate the essence of an article you should:
  1. First '''mark the text''' which describes the article's essence.
  2. Press '''Annotate''' in the '''Properties section''' of the '''semantic toolbar'''. The previously selected text is set as the '''value ("Page:")''' of the property.
  3. Now enter '''Example''' as name of the property. The system retrieves the type of this property and replaces the label '''"Page:" by "String"'''.
  4. Then press '''Add'''. The new annotation appears in the '''list of properties''', and the marked text is annotated.
  5. Now '''save''' the article.
    6. Below are some of the complications that you might encounter: * Looking at the factbox, you might see that the '''property Example might be undefined'''. This happens only for the very first time in a wiki, as '''Example''' is a completely normal property. * You may get this message: '''Example is an unknown property'''. If this happens, set the type of''' Example''' to string in the '''selection box''' that is the right. The page will be reloaded with the correct annotation. The article has now been annotated with the normal property '''Example'''. Some parts of the wiki and the reasoning system can however provide further features when they find it. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Annotating the essence of an article| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to access and use the online user manuals
UserManual:How to add a subquery to a query

revision.text:
This is a specific example in that it describes how to add a subquery to a query using an example of a sample query that you can formulate using the predefined categories and properties that are already predefined and shipped together with your SMW+ installation.
  1. Go to the special page '''Special:QueryInterface ''' or if you are using the WYSIWYG editor, click on the Query interface button in the WYSIWYG toolbar -this button has a small question mark and a small arrow and is located on the lower right section of the WYSIWYG editor toolbar.Proceed to define your query
  2. Click on the '''Add Category''' menu and add the Category as: Project
  3. Press '''Add'''
  4. Click on the '''Add Property''' menu and add Property as: Project member
  5. Activate the '''Show in results''' checkbox.
  6. Add restriction as subquery by activating the '''Subquery checkbox'''.
  7. Click '''Add''' or '''Update''' - this opens up an empty '''Query definition''' window which lets you define your subquery. Proceed to define your subquery.
  8. Click on the '''Add Property''' menu again and add property as: Birth date.
  9. Activate the '''Specific value''' checkbox under Restriction
  10. Set Property value as: greater(>=)15 July 1972
  11. Click '''Add''' - you should now see your query's result in the Result section and its tree in the Query as tree section
    12. Press the '''Ctrl+Alt+Space''' key combination to activate the autocomplete feature.
    {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Query interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to comment on an article

revision.text:
# Open an article in SMWforum you want to comment on # Click the hyperlink "add a comment" at the bottom of the article; this expands the form for entering a comment (see fig. "Form for entering a comment" # Enter the comment. # Click on the button "add comment" to save the comment.
Read more about comments {{LinkToHelp|Help:Commenting_articles|Help:Commenting articles}}. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:How to contribute| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to confirm a web service
UserManual:How to create an account in SMWFORUM
UserManual:How to define a query by adding a category

revision.text:
1. Go to the special page '''Special:QueryInterface ''' or if you are using the WYSIWYG editor, click on the Query interface button in the WYSIWYG toolbar -this button has a small question mark and a small arrow and is located on the lower right section of the WYSIWYG editor toolbar.
  2. Click on the '''Add Category''' menu
  3. Specify your category by entering its name in the text input box.
  4. Press the '''Add another category (OR) ''' link if you wish to add another category with a disjunction (OR).
  5. Press the '''Add''' button to add this category or press the '''Cancel''' link to exit the category menu without adding the category to your query.
    6. '''Note:''' Having done this, only the articles (instances) of this category will be displayed in the query results. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Query interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to define a query by adding a property

revision.text:
1. Go to the special page '''Special:QueryInterface ''' or if you are using the WYSIWYG editor, click on the Query interface button in the WYSIWYG toolbar -this button has a small question mark and a small arrow and is located on the lower right section of the WYSIWYG editor toolbar.
  2. Specify your property name by entering its name in the text input box.
  3. Define the '''Property value''' as follows: * Activate the '''Show in results''' checkbox to show the property explicitly in the results. The field Column label will be filled in with the property name you enter automatically. * Activate the '''Value must be set''' checkbox, to display only the results that include the mentioned property.
  4. Define your property restrictions as follows: * Activate the '''none''' checkbox to make no restrictions * Activate the '''Specific value''' checkbox to enter a specific value that should be fulfilled; you may further set the value as greater (>=) and less (>=) to properties that have the type number. * Activate the '''Subquery checkbox''' to add restrictions to the property in the form of a subquery. You may for example make a query about all project members who were born after using a predefined property.
    5. '''Note:''' Having done this, you specify a certain property that the results ought to fulfill. You may either list all results or define specific values. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Query interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to define a query by adding an Instance

revision.text:
1. Go to the special page '''Special:QueryInterface ''' or if you are using the WYSIWYG editor, click on Query interface button in the WYSIWYG toolbar -this button has a small question mark and a small arrow and is located on the lower right section of the WYSIWYG editor toolbar.
  2. Click on the '''Add Instance''' menu.
  3. Specify your instance name by entering its name in the text input box.
  4. Press the '''Add another instance (OR) ''' link if you wish to add another instance with a disjunction (OR).
  5. Press the '''Add''' button to add this instance or press the '''Cancel''' link to exit the Add Instance menu without adding the category to your query.
    6. '''Note:''' In doing this you specify the instance(s) such that only the specified ones are included in the query results. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Query interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to define a user group-specific navigation toolbar

revision.text:
The toolbox can be populated using the user-defined pages in the MediaWiki namespace. The name must have this format: '_Navigation_' followed by the group name. The users who are members of this group shall get the links that are in that page. If a user is member of several groups, he shall get all the links from the according pages (if they exist). Double links shall be filtered out. Links are defined as follows: 
*  [?url-parameters] |
The url parameters are optional. There are some predefined variables, namely: *'''PAGE_TITLE''': Page title with namespace prefix *'''PAGE_TITLE_WNS''': Page title without namespace prefix *'''PAGE_NS''': namespace prefix The last two variables may only be used in the 'url parameters' part.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=In order to include a specific toolbar for user group |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to file a feature request

revision.text:
If you have an idea for a new feature of SMW+ or the halo Extension then you can file a '''Feature Request''' in the SMWbugzilla.
;Follow these steps to enter the feature request #'''Open [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SemanticWiki SMWbugzilla]''' #'''Select the issue "Feature Request"''' #'''Select the component and version (a good guess is sufficient)''' #'''Formulate your idea in the "Description" field''' #'''Save the form'''
<big>Thank you! :-)</big>
;How do we handle feature requests? You should regularily verify the status of the feature request since the halo team is assessing them to see how to push them into the forthcoming release. In case your feature request becomes part of the implementation plan, then you will find a note in the bugzilla-entry.
It is also advisable that you check the [[Development/Release_Status|Release Status article]] in the development section. This gives you an idea what is included in the forthcoming releases.
'''Note''': You require an account in the SMWforum! [[Help:How_to_create_an_account_in_SMWFORUM|Read here how to create an account in the SMW+ User Forum.]] {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/22 |answer=Create an account in the smwforum (incl. email adress!) and enter the halo-bugzilla. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:How to contribute| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:How to report a bug

revision.text:
To file a bug report you need an account (incl. EMail-adress) in the SMWforum.
'''Read here how to create an account: {{LinkToHelp|Help:How to create an account in SMWFORUM|creating an account in the SMWforum}}.''' You can file bug reports for: * [[#a_bug_in_your_SMW.2B_or_Halo_installation|a bug in your {{SMW+}} or Halo installation]] * [[#a_bug_in_the_SMWforum_installation|a bug in the SMWforum installation]] * [[#an_issue_with_an_article_of_the_SMWforum|an issue with an article of the SMWforum]] * [[#a_feature_request_for_SMW.2B_or_Halo|a feature request for {{SMW+}} or Halo]] __NOTOC__
== a bug in your {{SMW+}} installation == If you found a bug in your {{SMW+}} installation we would like to know about it so we can fix it quickly. Please verify at first if your issue is really a bug: #Reproduce your issue using one of ontoprise's SMW+ reference installations: #::'''[http://halo-smw.ontoprise.com/ reference SMW+ installations]''' #::(please select the one which comes nearest to your configuration) #Search Bugzilla, to see whether your issue has already been reported: #::'''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/buglist.cgi?classification=MediaWiki%20extensions&classification=Microsoft%20Office%20Products&classification=Semantic%20Enterprise%20Wiki%20%28SMW%2B%29&classification=SMW%2B%20Extension%20Suite&classification=Triplestore%20products&query_format=advanced&bug_status=NEW&bug_status=ASSIGNED&bug_status=REOPENED&cf_issuetype=Bug list of current issues in bugzilla]''' After you have followed these checks you can file the bug in SMWbugzilla (if you want a more detailed description of the required data then you might find the {{LinkToHelp|Help:Guidelines_for_filing_a_software_bug_in_SMWbugzilla|guidelines for filing a software bug}} helpful.
[[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=Semantic%20Enterprise%20Wiki%20%28SMW%2B%29 File a bug for a SMW+ installation]''' :SMW+ contains the following parts: [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=Halo+extension+core Halo Extension], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=Deployment+Framework Deployment Framework], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=Smwplus%20bundle Smwplus], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=Smwplus%20sandbox%20bundle Smwplussandbox], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=Enhanced+Retrieval Enhanced retrieval extension] and [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMW%2B&component=WYSIWYG+extension WYSIWYG extension] [[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=MediaWiki%20extensions File a bug for a MediaWiki extensions]''' :There you find the extensions [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Halo%20Access%20Control%20List%20extension Access Control List] and [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=WYSIWYG%20%28will%20be%20redirected%29 WYSIWYG] that are provided by Ontoprise [[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=SMW%2B%20Extension%20Suite File a bug for another extension which is not contained in the SMW+ installation]''' :There you find all other extensions that are part of the Halo project but which are not contained in the SMW+ installation [[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=Triplestore%20products File a bug for Triple Store products]''' :There you find the products [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Triplestore%20Basic TripleStore basic (Jena)] and [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Triplestore%20Professional TripleStore Professional (Ontobroker)] [[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=Microsoft%20Office%20Products File a bug for Microsoft Office Connectors]''' :There you find the products [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Microsoft%20Excel%20Connector Microsoft Excel Connector], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Microsoft%20Office%20Connector Microsoft Office Connector], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Microsoft%20Project%20Connector Microsoft Project Connector], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=Semantic%20Connector Semantic Connector], [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=WikiTag WikiTag]
== a bug in the SMWforum installation == If you encounter a bug in the software installation on SMWForum we'd like to know about it so we can quickly fix it. To do this we need the following information: *A description of the bug (If possible the scenario or an example we can use to reproduce the bug) *Your browser (Firefox, Internet Explorer, Safari, other)
[[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''{{Link_to_file_SMWforum_software_bug|File your bug.}}'''
== an issue with an article of the SMWforum == If you found a problem in one of the articles on SWMForum please report them so they can get fixed. To quickly solve the issue we need: *A description of the bug (If possible the scenario or an example we can use to reproduce the bug) *The URL of the article in question
[[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwbugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=SMWForum File your issue.]'''
== a feature request for {{SMW+}} or Halo == If you want to propose a new feature please read {{LinkToHelp|Help:How_to_file_a_feature_request|How to file a feature request in SMWbugzilla}}.
[[Image:Pfeil.gif|10px]] '''{{LinkToHelp|Help:How_to_file_a_feature_request|Find out how to file a feature request.}}'''
{{Warning|Do not use special characters in the title of the bug!!!}} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/22 |answer=Create an account in the smwforum (incl. email adress!) and enter the halo-bugzilla. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:How to contribute| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}
