page.title: UserManual:What about the annotation proposals
UserManual:What are Annotations
UserManual:What are Automatic Semantic Forms
UserManual:What are Namespaces

revision.text:
Pages without a '''':'''' in their name are in the main namespace. These are typically the bulk of the content pages in a wiki. Pages which aren't directly related to this core content, may go in other namespaces. These pages have a name of the form "''namespace'':''page''" A typical scheme would be as follows: *'''Help :''' Documentation about working with the wiki software. *'''Image:''' For descriptions of uploaded files or media files.They are created when you click the [[Special:Upload|Upload file]] link in the toolbox. *'''Media:'''Use this namespace to link to uploaded files directly, rather than through the description pages. *'''MediaWiki: '''Use this namespace to change the default system messages. Project Information about this wiki. *'''Talk: '''Each page has a corresponding '''''discussion''''' page. *'''Template: '''This is used for meta-information that is to be transcluded into multiple documents, such as tags to mark the status of a document. *'''User:''' For personal notes. Each User has a corresponding user page for their own information. *'''User_talk''' The discussion page on a user's page can be used for leaving messages. If this page is edited, the next time that user logs in they will see a box notifying them that they have new messages.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=A way to organize the wiki space: they allow, among others, a separation of content from policy and discussion. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using Namespaces 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are Semantic Forms
UserManual:What are Special pages

revision.text:
'''Special pages''' are pages that are created by the software on demand. They are located in their own namespace '''''Special:'''''  and they may not be edited directly like other pages. Some special pages depend on the preferences that have been set by a user, e.g. the number of titles which is displayed on a user's watchlist.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/14 |answer=Special pages are pages that are created by the software on demand. They are located in their own namespace ''Special:'' and are not editable directly as other pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Overview of special pages 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are categories

revision.text:
*A '''category''' is a software feature of MediaWiki. Categories provide automatic indexes that are useful as tables of contents. Together with links and templates they structure a project. *Each of the pages in the '''Category''' namespace represents a so-called '''category''', a kind of grouping of related pages. When a page belongs to one or more categories, this information appears at the bottom of the page (or in the upper-right corner, depending on the skin being used). *You can assign a category to a page simply by adding "[[Category:''Category name'']]" to the page's wikitext source. So as to reference a category within a page as a normal wiki link (without adding the page to the category) you should prefix the link name with a colon. For example: [[:Category:Not in this category]].
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=A way of structuring the contents of a wiki. You can add a page to categories by adding category tags to that page |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating hierarchies of categories 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are data types
UserManual:What are datatypes and units of measurement
UserManual:What are domains and ranges

revision.text:
The domain is the subject of an attribute's relation, just like the grammatical subject in an ordinary sentence: A person has a firstname. In this case the property 'Firstname' has the domain and [[range]] 'Person': [[Has domain and range::Category:Person| ]] Normally it is sufficient, to create a property (e.g. ''Property:atomic weight'') and assign a type to it (e.g.''[[has type::Type:float''). The problem is that the property can be used in every article of any category. As a result of this, even a car could end up having an 'atomic weight'. To find out errors of this kind, the articles for properties should be annotated with a domain and range hint. The article for ''Property:atomic weight'' should for example contain the following line: [[has domain and range::Category:Atom]]
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=Domain is the category that can use (instanciate) the property and range is the category whose instances can be used as values of the property |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::OntologyBrowser| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Domain and Range 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are double redirects

revision.text:
A so called '''double redirect''' occurs when one attempts to create a redirect to a page that is also already a redirect. Such redirects will not work since multiple directing will not follow through to the end of the chain. Users will instead just be presented with the relevant link, which is a view of the redirect page. This is a deliberate restriction, partly to prevent infinite loops and also to keep things simple. It serves the purpose of preventing the creation of rather unpleasant and complicated tree of redirects! However this does mean that you should look out for double redirects and eliminate them by changing them to be 1-step redirects. This is mostly necessary only if you do a significant page move. Use the 'what links here' toolbox link to find double redirects to a particular page, or use [[Special:DoubleRedirects|Special:DoubleRedirects]] to search through the entire wiki.

{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/22 |answer=Pages redirecting to other pages which are themselves redirects |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Handling redirects 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are edit conflicts
UserManual:What are interwiki links

revision.text: '''Interwiki links''' are links to pages of other projects. They are prefixed in internal link style. Interwiki links make it possible to for example link to pages of Wikipedia, Wikibooks, Wikinews etc. or to your wiki-project in different languages. A link like [[Wikipedia:Main Page]] will appear like this: [[Wikipedia:Main Page]] and it will redirect you to Wikipedia's Main Page. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=Interwiki links are links to pages of other projects, using a prefixed internal link style |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are multiple-instance templates

revision.text:
Adding the multiple parameter to a template lets you use multiple instances of this template’s (or none) in the form and thereby also in the generated page. The sample form below, for the '''Item''' form, contains two such templates. If you look at the form that this definition generates, you will notice that there are two buttons labelled: '''Add another'''. Clicking on either of these buttons will create a new instance of that template and its field(s).

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/10 }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining Semantic Forms| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are n-ary properties

revision.text:
N-ary properties are like binary properties with additional conditions.They can have '''several values at a time'''.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |url=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=Properties with more than one type |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Annotating a n-ary property 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are n-ary relations

revision.text: An '''n-ary relation''' is a relation that maps between a subject and '''two or more''' values. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=Properties with more than one type |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Editing a n-ary property| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are patrolled edits

revision.text:
'''Patrolled edits''' is a feature which allows specific users to mark items in recent changes as having been '''patrolled''' or '''approved'''. This is usually only available if you have sysop permissions by default.
'''''Customization''':''
All the MediaWiki versions 1.6 through 1.8 have ''user preference'' page that is available to users who have permission to mark edits as patrolled. If set, the edits made by these users are automatically marked as partolled.
In MediaWiki 1.9, this user preference has been removed and replaced by a new '''autopatrol '''right, which is only assigned to sysops by default. In addition to this users cannot mark their own edits as patrolled.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2010/04/22 |answer=Allowing specific users to mark items in recent changes as having been |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are properties

revision.text:
In SMW+, a property gives machine-processable description of some feature of an object, such as its weight, size, location, or its owner. The property is written as an annotation in the article about the object that it describes.
Properties that establish relationships between two pages this way are sometimes called relations.A property can have, but does not require, a page in the wiki.
The special properties appear in italics in the factbox of pages that use them, '''do not use''' these reserved names as your own properties. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=In SMW+, a property gives machine-processable description of some feature of an object, such as its weight, size, location, or its owner. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating a new property 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are redirects

revision.text:
Redirects are used to forward users from one page name to another. They can be useful if a particular article is referred to by multiple names, or has alternative punctuation, capitalization or spellings. You can: *'''Create a redirect''', but not '''a double redirect'''. *'''View a redirect'''. *'''Delete a redirect'''. *'''Make a redirect to a page in the category namespace'''.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=Redirects are used to forward users from one page name to another. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Handling redirects 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are relations

revision.text: A '''relation''' refers to the machine-processable description of the relationship between two objects. In SMW+, it's a property of '''Type:Page''' that relates one article to another; '''Type:Page''' is the default type of a property. A relation is annotated by adding a property to an existing MediaWiki link, using the syntax [[property name::link target]] A relation always describes a directed relationship between the article with the annotation and the article that is the target of a link. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=A property of Type:Page that relates one article to another |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME link::| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are semantic templates

revision.text:
'''Semantic templates''' are a method of including additional annotation mark-up into templates. This has several advantages: *Users can specify annotations without having to learning any new syntax. *Annotations are used consistently, i.e. users do not have to look for the right properties or categories when editing a page. *Since templates also have other functions, such as rendering flashy infoboxes in an article, users are motivated to use them.

{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Templates which include annotation markup |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticForms| ]] [[UME link::Help:What are Semantic templates 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are service links

revision.text:
SMW+ can provide links to online services when printing certain data in the factbox. For example, when a geographic coordinate is entered into an article, it is useful to provide links to online mapping services, so that users can retrieve a map of the specified area with one click.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Links to online services, that appear in the factbox next to printed data |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding service links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are special properties

revision.text:
There are predefined properties that have special functions even if you do not create property pages for them in your wiki. You cannot use these names as your own properties. SMW 1.0 has the following special properties:
[[Property:Allows value|Allows value]], [[Property:Corresponds to|Corresponds to]], [[Property:Display units|Display units]], [[Property:Equivalent URI|Equivalent URI]], [[Property:Has type|Has type]], [[Property:Imported from|Imported from]], [[Property:Provides service|Provides service]], and [[Property:Subproperty of|Subproperty of]]. Additionally, [[Property:Display unit|Display unit]] is an alias for [[Property:Display units|Display unit'''s''']]. These internal special properties do not appear in the [[Special:Properties|Special:Properties]] list, you cannot query them and a special property's page does not show the pages using these properties.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=SMW has predefined special properties that have special meaning |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME link::Help:Viewing all properties, types and values 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are sub- and super properties

revision.text:
Below are the steps to follow while defining sub- and superproperties:
  1. First '''create''' the article '''''Property''''':is parent of. Write some descriptive text and '''save''' it.
  2. Then '''create''' the article '''''Property''''':is father of. Write some descriptive text and '''add '''the annotation: 
    [[subproperty of::Property:is parent of]]
  3. Now '''Save''' the article.
  4. Finally reopen the article ''Property:'''''is parent of'''. Now it should show its sub-relation ''is '''''father of'''.

    5. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=e.g. has relative is a superproperty of has parent, while has father is a subproperty of has parent |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Defining sub- and superproperties| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are subpages

revision.text:
'''Subpages''' introduce some hierarchical organization into wiki page names, with levels of the hierarchy that are separated by slashes ''''/''''.
*'''Namespaces''':
The '''subpage''' feature is ussually turned '''off by default''' in the main namespace. It may be used on the talk pages and the user pages.
*'''Slashes within a page name''': 
Slashes (/) within a page name break the page into parent and subpages, recursively, eg:
#Example page #Example page/Some sub-page #Example page/Some sub-page/Some sub-sub-page
*'''Using (and over-using) sub pages''':
There are various uses for the subpage mechanism. The main two intended uses are:
#On a '''''talk page''''' create a subpage (or several) for an archiving of old discussions #On a '''''user page''''' create a subpage (or several) to use as a scratchpad editing space.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Subpages introduce some hierarchical organisation into wiki page names, with levels of the hierarchy separated by slashes '/' |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are templates

revision.text:
MediaWiki template feature lets you use '''standard '''texts time and again in '''several pages'''. For example, the box above is included in all pages in the Help namespace).
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=A way of including standard text into several pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:What are Semantic templates 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are types

revision.text:
A '''Type''' identifies a subject with a class. In SMW+, type is more specifically the datatype of a property. It is specified with the [[Property:Has_type|Property:Has type]] special property which relates the property to a to a particular datatype in the Type namespace.
The [[Special:Types|Special:Types]] page has a list of all built-in and custom datatypes. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Some identification of a subject with a class or the datatype of properties |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Semantic Toolbar| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What are variables

revision.text:
Variables in MediaWiki serve the purpose of inserting certain values that change in pages. 
The way they are rendered varies according to the following conditions: #The '''time''' - directly depending on the time or depending on the creation of other articles if we for example consider a number of article. #The '''project''' - it changes whenever the wikitext is copied. #The '''page''' in which it occurs - it changes whenever the wikitext is copied, when the page is renamed and when the page is included in another page. To the left you will find the variable and to the right you will see how it is rendered at this time, in this project and on this page. The names of the variables form part of the set of so-called '''magic words''' which are used by the system. With '''Special:ExpandTemplates''' one can view the value of a variable, or from a broader perspective, the expanded wikitext that a variable or a wikitext with variables and/or '''template''' calls produces, as an intermediate step towards rendering. {{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=The names of the variables form part of the set of so-called |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Variables| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What basic navigation elements are there in a wiki

revision.text:
When viewing any page on a MediaWiki wiki, you'll find three main navigation elements:
#The '''sidebar''' that is to the left gives you access to important pages in the wiki such as ''Recent changes'' or ''Upload file''. #The top of the page has links which are often refered to as '''tabs'''. They are related to the page that is currently displayed .i.e. its associated discussion page, the version history and most notably the edit link. #At the top right corner, you'll find user '''links'''.
*If you are visiting the page as an anonymous user, you will see a link that lets you '''create an account''' or '''log in'''. The two pages are identical. *If you are logged in , you should see a collection of personal links, including links to your '''user page''' and your '''preferences'''.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=The Sidebar, the Page Tabs and the User links |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Changing Links in the Navigation Box| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What can I do if I have SMW and/or SF installed manually and I want to use the Deployment Framework

revision.text:
You already have SMW or Semantic Forms installed and you wish to use the Deployment Framework.
'''Solution'''
"Lift" your installation:
*Manually: Add DF tags and deploy descriptors.
*Automatically: For the extensions SemanticMediawiki and SemanticForms.
#Open a console in admin mode and change to deployment/tools/maintenance.
#Run:
php checkInstallation.php --lift
SMW and SF are search and lifted if found. Check by running: swmadmin -l. It should show both extensions as installed via DF. {{ShowComments |show=True }} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise |year=2011 |date retrieved=2011/04/15 }} [[UME discourse state::CheckInstallation| ]] [[UME link::Help:Troubleshooting for common problems with the Deployment Framework| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

UserManual:What can I specify in Property Properties

revision.text:
The properties of a property are: *'''Domain''': articles of this category can have values for this property. *'''Range''': Articles in this category are objects of the property. This field is only enabled if the property's type is '''Page'''. *'''Inverse of''': the name of the property that is the inverse of the current property. *'''Type''': One of the predefined types :*The type '''Page''' indicates that the property's values are wiki articles. :*Their '''Range''' defines the category of articles. :*The type '''N-ary''' indicates that the property can have several ranges and types. *'''Minimal cardinality''': The minimum number of property values. This field is disabled if the properties type is of '''N-ary''' type. *'''Maximum cardinality''': the maximum number of the values of the property. This field is not enabled when the properties type is ''N-ary''. *'''Transitivity''': defines that the property is transitive. This field is only enabled, if the property's type is '''Page'''. *'''Symmetry''': defines that the property is symmetric. This field is only enabled, if the property's type is '''Page'''.
When a property definition article is opened for editing, the '''Property Properties''' is initialized according to the wiki text. When schema relevant properties are changed in the wiki text, they are updated in the semantic toolbar after a short delay. .
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME discourse state::Property| ]] [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Specifying property properties 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What does the highlighting indicate

revision.text:
Below are the interpretations of various color, highlight, background and border indicators:
*'''Properties''' are highlighted with an '''orange '''background. *'''Categories''' you annotate in a session are highlighted with a '''blue''' background. The next time you open the article in AAM, this highlight will be gone, because category annotations are normally invisible in the rendered article. *'''Page links''' are treated as annotation proposals and are surrounded with a '''green border''' and a green button (+) offers enhancing the link with an annotation.
*Content that was generated by '''templates''' gets a '''blue overlay'''. For each used template there is a blue button (<nowiki>{{}}</nowiki>) that links to the templates definition.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=orange = property, blue = new categories/templates, green border = proposal |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME link::Help:Advanced Annotation Mode| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What does the more tab show and can I customize it
UserManual:What does the orange highlight with black border indicate

revision.text:
When you switch to the annotation mode of an article, all properties and page links will be highlighted .  All annotations you '''add''' in a session are highlighted in '''orange with a black border'''. Example :  [[Image:High5.jpg]] This helps you can keep an '''overview''' of all the newly added annotations before you '''save''' your work.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=Annotations you add in a session |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME link::Help:Advanced Annotation Mode| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What does the triangle warning indicate
UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (FOAF Explorer)

revision.text:
'''[http://ontoworld.org/wiki/FOAF_Explorer FOAF Explorer]''' is an online viewer for RDF files that use the FOAF vocabulary.It can be accessed via [http://xml.mfd-consult.dk/foaf/explorer/ http://xml.mfd-consult.dk/foaf/explorer/].
Like most FOAF tools, FOAF Explorer is still somewhat limited and does not arbitrary RDF that just contains some FOAF statements. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/02/04 |answer=Geocoding Tools for Python, Tabulator, Longwell, FOAF Explorer, Piggy Bank, KAON2, OpenLink RDF Browser, and others |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Reuse| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (Geocoding Tools)
UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (KAON2)

revision.text:
'''[http://ontoworld.org/wiki/KAON2 KAON2]''' is a reasoner and ontology management API for OWL DL and SWRL. It can be used to check the validity of the exported OWL specifications. When used together with [http://ontoworld.org/wiki/OWL_tools OWL tools], one can also transform the exported RDF into [http://ontoworld.org/wiki/LaTeX LaTeX] sources that show the related DL statements. These statements tend to be more readable for humans, or at least for the people who have knowledge about DL.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/02/04 |answer=Geocoding Tools for Python, Tabulator, Longwell, FOAF Explorer, Piggy Bank, KAON2, OpenLink RDF Browser, and others |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Reuse| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (Longwell)

revision.text:
'''[http://ontoworld.org/wiki/Longwell Longwell]''' is a Java-based faceted browser for RDF.
It includes features for browsing, querying and query refinement, Timeline support and graphical presentation of RDF graphs.
It works very well with the RDF's generated by SMW+ and its faceted browsing capabilities provide some real added value for the semantic data. It is available online from http://simile.mit.edu/longwell/.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/02/04 |answer=Geocoding Tools for Python, Tabulator, Longwell, FOAF Explorer, Piggy Bank, KAON2, OpenLink RDF Browser, and others |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Reuse| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (Piggy Bank)
UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (RDF Browser)
UserManual:What external tools can be used with SMW+ (Tabulator)

revision.text:
A '''[http://ontoworld.org/wiki/Tabulator Tabulator]''' is an online browser for RDF documents available at http://www.w3.org/2005/10/ajaw/tab.html.
Using it on external resources such as ontoworld.org requires a change in security settings of the browser, since JavaScript must be enabled to access external sites. Once this is done, RDF of ontoworld can be loaded conveniently by loading the URL of some RDF export, e.g. http://wiki.ontoworld.org/index.php/Special:ExportRDF/ESWC2006.
The interface is still somewhat not fully refined, but the tool shows that dynamic interfaces for browsing RDF and RDF-enabled sites are feasible. Tabulator takes advantage of SMW+'s feature of creating ''browsable RDF'' which also includes "backlinks" in RDF triples.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/02/04 |answer=Geocoding Tools for Python, Tabulator, Longwell, FOAF Explorer, Piggy Bank, KAON2, OpenLink RDF Browser, and others |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Reuse| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What if the menu is not displayed
UserManual:What is a Talk page
UserManual:What is a User page

revision.text:
A '''user page''' is a web-based display of information relating to a certain wiki user. This is someone who is registered on the wiki and is in most cases also a contributor and the author of pages. Once registered, one may create his own user page which is linked on the page’s top right pane.
Moreover, others will see links to your user page from various places thereby assisting in wiki collaboration. Such places include the '''Recent changes''' and the page '''history''' pages.
You may also link to your user page within a wiki page’s text. This is mainly useful on '''talk pages''' as you sign and associate an article with your name.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=A |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Working with user pages 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is a concept
UserManual:What is a magic word

revision.text:
A '''magic word''' is a symbol which recognized by the MediaWiki software. Whenever it is used in a page text and not as a comment, it triggers some specific function. It may for example transclude a page with the given name, instead of just appearing in the text.
Whenever it is used in a page text and not as a comment, it triggers some specific function. It may for example transclude a page with the given name, instead of just appearing in the text. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/12 |answer=There's a long list of magic words: |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using wiki magicwords 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is a query

revision.text:
Typically, a '''query''' might be formulated as follows: *Show all cities in Germany with a population greater than 500,000; display the name of each city, its population, and its surface area. *By formulating a query, you can ask that the system generates a table, which can be displayed in various ways. *Each row in the table shows information about one '''instance''' i.e., city, object, person,etc, that is described on a page of its own: :'''The name''' of the instance i.e.- the title of the page that describes it, e.g. "Berlin". :The values of some ''''properties''' of the instance (one property per column; e.g., population, surface area). *The building blocks of a query are '''restrictions'''. *You can also make the following specifications in a query
  1. Determine the properties that are to be displayed in the columns
  2. Determine how the table is to be formatted-e.g. how the rows are to be sorted
    3. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/26 |answer=A way to obtain information from the wiki. Example: |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Graphical Query Interface| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is a watchlist

revision.text:
Watching pages feature allows any logged in user to keep a list of "watched" pages and to be notified of recent edits to these pages. Here are a some of the things you should know about the ''' watch lists''' :
  1. When the user is logged in, every page has a link to the user's watchlist. This page is also accessible by following this link: [http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Special:Watchlist Special:Watchlist].
    This page shows a list of all recently changed watched pages, separated by days, ordered backward according to the time of the edit. Technically, the watchlist is just another way '''of filtering''' recent changes.
  2. By default watchlist (simple watchlist) only shows the last edit that was made on each watched page. There are two possible problems if a page had a non-minor recent edit, but the last edit was marked as minor: *Non-minor edits will not be shown. Since one is typically interested in all the changes that were made since the last time, in this case the history of the page needs to be checked. *If watchlist is set such that it does not to show minor changes, then the page will not appear in the watchlist at all.
  3. Many experienced users prefer to use Expanded Watchlist. If one uses the preference, '''Expand watchlist to show all applicable changes''', the watchlist will show all recent edits, listed in chronological order. In this case the preference '''Enhanced recent changes (JavaScript)''', which toggles enhanced recent changes, also has the same effect : recent changes of watched pages are grouped by day, and within a day by page.
    4. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/26 |answer=accessible by the link Special:Watchlist |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Watchlist| ]] [[UME link::Help:Watching pages| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is an inline query

revision.text:
SMW+ includes a simple query language for semantic search. It lets users request certain information from the wiki directly. Readers who do not wish to learn the query syntax can still profit from this feature: *'''inline queries''' dynamically include query results into pages. So queries created by a few editors can be used by many readers. Inline queries are similar to other semantic search features, and can also be restricted on a site in order to ensure sufficient performance. Since inline queries exploit the existing caching mechanisms of '''MediaWiki''', most requests for a page with such dynamic contents can be served without any performance impact whatsoever.
{{Copyright of article |own work=False |copyright holder=Semantic MediaWiki |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=Query results which are dynamically included into pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticSearch| ]] [[UME link::Help:Creating inline queries 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is semantic search

revision.text:
SMW+ includes an easy-to-use '''query language''' which enables you to access the wiki's knowledge. The syntax of this query language is similar to the syntax of annotations in SMW+. This query language can be used on the special page [[Special:Ask|Special:Ask]] or in inline queries.
It is clear that answering queries requires additional resources and the administrators of some sites may choose to switch off or restrict most of the features in order to ensure that even high-traffic sites can handle the additional load. {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=SMW+ includes an easy-to-use query language which enables users to access the wiki's knowledge |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticSearch| ]] [[UME link::Help:Semantic Search| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is shownow parser function

revision.text:
The #show parser function which enables you to easily query for annotations of an instance, would have been appropriate for that purpose were it not for this one major issue - the #show parser function always displays the state of the instance before the last edit of the instance.
For example, if an instance contains the annotation [[Has title::Title]] and if one now edits that article and changes the annotation to [[Has title::New title]], then the result of the #show parser function in the saved article is still Title until someone refreshes or edits the article again.
The Automatic Semantic Forms extension therefore introduced the #shownow parser function, which immediately displays the current annotation values even when they have been edited.
The syntax of the new #shownow parser function is shown below: {{#shownow: ?property-title | linked | variable | evaluate }} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise |year=2011 |date retrieved=2011/03/24 }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using 'Display templates'| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the Factbox

revision.text:
Below is some useful information about the '''Factbox''': *The '''Factbox''' is a box that is located at the bottom of wiki pages. It summarizes the semantic data that was entered into the page. *Users looking at the '''Factbox''' get a quick overview and they may use its links to get further information. *'''Factboxes''' show information in two columns:
#The left column displays the property. #The right column shows the value of that property.
*In some cases the '''Factbox''' may also shows links to external web services. *The '''factbox''' has a link which may be used to retrieve the Factbox contents in the machine-readable OWL/RDF format.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=The box at the bottom of wiki pages which summarizes the semantic data that was entered into that page |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Summarized Semantic Data in Factbox| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the FindWork special page

revision.text:
The '''FindWork''' special page was created so that it may propose pages to users. These proposed pages should be the pages that the user is most probably interested in. It's important to be logged, although one may use the page anonymously. The user can use this page in two ways: #Pressing '''Give me some work''' gives the user a list of pages with random gardening issues. This is done in re-spect to his edit-history. #You can be more specific and choose a class of issues. The navigation works just like in all MW query pages: *There are previous/next buttons that help you choose the amount of results to be displayed at one particular time. *The user can click on '''Show details''' to get to the GardeningLog special page and view the details of that particular page.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=It suggests new work for a user which should match his interests |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::FindWork| ]] [[UME link::Help:Finding pages that need improvement 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the Gardening Log special page
UserManual:What is the LDAP authentification

revision.text:
'''LDAP''' is a hierarchical database used as a directory service. It's commonly used as a central authentication service by many applications. Since there is an LDAP extension for MW, wiki users can also be authenticated by an LDAP server.
It's possible to manage only users or both users and groups on an LDAP server.
You can additionally use the LDAP server together with the normal authentication mechanism of MW during a migration process.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=LDAP is a hierarchical database used as a directory service |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using LDAP authentication| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the OntologyBrowser

revision.text:
The OntologyBrowser has 3 basic views: #The '''CategoryView''': Shows category hierarchy, called the taxonomy of the wiki -it can be changed to show the attribute and relation hierarchy with the buttons above it. #The '''InstanceView''': Shows either the instances that belong to a certain category when triggered from category view, or the instances that are annotated with a certain category when triggered from property view. #The '''PropertyView''': Shows either the annotated properties when triggered from instance view, or the schema properties when triggered from category view.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/11 |answer=The ontology browser allows easy and intuitive lookup of information from the knowledgebase in 3 basic views |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::OntologyBrowser| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Ontology browser 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the Property Properties box
UserManual:What is the context sensitive auto completion

revision.text:
The auto completion of properties in the '''Advanced Annotation Mode''' (AAM) is context sensitive.
Auto completion will always try to find the matching properties for: *Dates *email addresses *numerical values with units of measurement, *numbers and *articles that belong to categories.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=The auto completion tries to match the types of properties with annotated values |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::Annotate| ]] [[UME link::Help:Using Autocompletion 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the context sensitive help

revision.text:
The '''Context Sensitive Help''' ('''CSH''') feature supports you as you use Semantic MediaWiki. *If you use the '''''OntoSkin''''' as your default skin in this wiki, you should see the question mark at the top of your page. *If you are using any other skin apart from the modern skin, you should see the name '''''Help''''' at the top of your page. CSH offers help contents based on your current action and location in the wiki. The CSH will show different help questions and provide corresponding answers in line with your current action. Users may read these help contents. You may even ask new questions ,answer unanswered questions or even give feedback.
{{ShowComments|show=True}} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2009/11/23 |answer=A section in the toolbar which shows help topics that could be useful in your current workflow |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Context Sensitive Help| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the difference between the 'go' and the 'search'-button
UserManual:What is the master template for initial rights
UserManual:What is the navigation box

revision.text:
The navigation box is a menu which contains various links. It is located in the left section of the wiki page. These links will take you to the wiki's most important pages and site administrators can configure them.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=The menu on the left hand side of the screen which contains links to important pages in your wiki |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::General| ]] [[UME link::Help:Changing Links in the Navigation Box| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the path search
UserManual:What is the query interface

revision.text:
The '''Query Interface''' lets you use inline queries to retrieve specific semantic data in your wiki. It formulates the queries for you such that you do not have to master the '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:Inline_Queries #ask syntax]''' which is eventually used to make these queries. The '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:What_is_a_query query]''' interface now helps you to exploit the full power of Semantic MediaWiki's query mechanism. It provides a graphical user interface that supports you in building semantic queries in an intuitive manner. It was created with the view of giving the less experienced users a methodology of using queries without having to learn the rather complex '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Help:Inline_Queries #ask syntax]'''. This was done by integrating a query interface into SMWHalo/SMW+ and it allows users to make queries easily. The query interface is a special page and can therefore be accessed on the page '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Special:QueryInterface Special:QueryInterface]''', which is linked from '''[http://smwforum.ontoprise.com/smwforum/index.php/Special:SpecialPages Special:Specialpages]'''. You might want to read: ''' [[Help:Description_of_the_Query_Interface_1.5.3|What can I do with the Query Interface?]]'''
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/12/02 |answer=It is a special page, with which queries can be created graphically. |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::QueryInterface| ]] [[UME link::Help:Description of the Query Interface 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the semantic toolbar

revision.text:
The semantic toolbar appears in the '''annotate''' and '''edit''' tabs of each page and contains tools for the semantic annotation of wiki text and the definition of the wiki's ontology in form of properties and categories. It shows the current annotations in the wiki text and is updated regularly when the text changes. The semantic toolbar can be used with MediaWiki's standard text editor or with the syntax highlighting editor. Annotations may be contributed to an article by templates. These annotations are ignored by the semantic toolbar. However, the content of templates can be edited with the semantic toolbar.
{{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=A part of the user interface with tools that make it easy for you to use the semantic features of the wiki when editing or annotating a page |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SemanticToolbar| ]] [[UME link::Help:Semantic Toolbar| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What is the similarities bot
UserManual:What kind of pages exist
UserManual:What simple semantic search interfaces exist

revision.text:
Semantic MediaWiki has a number of very simple search forms which allow users to find specific information.
These search features can be accessed from special pages: *[[Special:SearchByProperty|Special:SearchByProperty]] has a simple search form for finding ''semantic backlinks''.
If you enter a property name and target value, the search will return a list of all pages that have the property with that value. This service may be accessed directly by following this link [[Image:Search icon.png|search button]] within the Factbox. *[[Special:PageProperty|Special:PageProperty]] displays all the values that a page has for some property. You enter a page and a property name, the search displays a list of all values of the property on that page. If Factboxes are enabled in the wiki, one can get the same information from a page's Factbox . {{ Cite web in help |wiki=Semantic MediaWiki |url=http://semantic-mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Browsing_interfaces#Simple_search_interfaces |title=Help:Browsing interfaces. Simple search interfaces |retrieved=2008-04-07 |lastmodified=2008-03-27 |publisher=Semantic MediaWiki }} {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2009 |date retrieved=2009/11/10 |answer=The special pages |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::SpecialPages| ]] [[UME link::Help:Semantic Search| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}

page.title: UserManual:What system requirements does OntoSkin3 have
UserManual:What types of links exist

revision.text:
There are four types of links : *'''Internal Links '''are links to other wiki pages.'''
''' *'''External Links '''are links to pages in other websites.'''
''' *'''Interwiki Links '''are links to other websites that are registered to the wiki in advance.'''
''' *'''Interlanguage Links '''are links to other websites registered as other wiki language versions.'''
''' {{Copyright of article |own work=True |copyright holder=Ontoprise GmbH |year=2010 |date retrieved=2009/02/15 |answer=N-ary properties are annotated in the same way as normal ones |for_releases=all }} [[UME discourse state::EditWikisyntax| ]] [[UME link::Help:Adding links 1.5.3| ]] {{Content hash|value=}} {{Part of bundle|value=Smwusermanual}}
